Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Volpone
Bibliographical reference: Jonson, Ben.  "Volpone." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby 1616. 440-524.  489; act 3, scene 7, lines 164-182 [normalized spelling].
Text:
SONG.
Come my Caelia let us prove
While we can the sports of love
Time will not be ours for ever
He at length our good will sever
spend not then his giftes in vain.
Suns, that set, may rise again.
But if, once, we lose this light
'Tis with us perpetual night
Why should we defer our joys
Fame, and rumour are but toys.
Cannote we delude the eyes
Of a few poor household spies?
Or his easier ears beguile,
Thus removÃ¨d by our wile?
It's no sin loves fruits to steal,
But the sweet thefts to reveal.
To be taken, to be seen
These have crimes accounted been.
Modifications: WoSo#004234 Come Sweet Caelia let us prove...
URL:
SONG.
Come my Caelia let us proue
While we can the sports of loue
Time will not be ours for ever
He at length our good will seuer
spend not then his giftes in vaine.
Sunnes, that set, may rise again.
But if, once, we lose this light
'Tis with us perpetuall night
Why should we deferre our ioyes
Fame, and rumor are but toies.
Cannote we delude the eyes
Of a few poor houshold spies?
Or his easier eares beguile,
Thus remooued by our wile?
It's no sinne, loues fruits to steale,
But the sweet thefts to reueale.
To be taken, to be seene
These haue crimes accounted beene.
Internal comment: Jonson, Ben.  "Volpone." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby 1616. 440-524.  489; act 3, scene 7, lines 164-182.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Volpone
Bibliographical reference: Jonson, Ben.  "Volpone." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby 1616. 440-524.  453; act 1, scene 2, lines 42-47 [normalized spelling].
Text:
[Nano:] O wonderful change! when Sir Lawyer forsook thee,
For PYTHAGORAS' sake, what body then took thee?
[Androgyno:] A good dull mule.
[Nano:] And how! by that means,
Thou wert brought to allow of the eating of beans?
[Androgyno:] Yes.
[Nano:] But, from the mule, into whom didst thou pass?
 [Androgyno:] Into a very strange beast, by some writers cal'd an ass,
By others, a precise, pure, illuminate brother,
Of those devour flesh, and sometimes one another:
And will drop you forth a libel, or a sanctified lie,
Betwixt every spoonful of a nativity-pie.
Modifications: WoPh#004235 But from the mule into whom didst thou pass
URL:
[Nano:] O wonderfull change! when Sir Lawyer forsooke thee,
For PYTHAGORE'S sake, what body then tooke thee?
[Androgyno:] A good dull moyle.
[Nano:] And how! by that meanes,
Thou wert brought to allow of the eating of beanes?
[Androgyno:] Yes.
[Nano:] But, from the moyle, into whom did'st thou passe?
 [Androgyno:] Into a very strange beast, by some writers cal'd an asse,
By others, a precise, pure, illuminate brother,
Of those deuoure flesh, and sometimes one another:
And will drop you forth a libell, or a sanctified lie,
Betwixt euery spoonefull of a natiuitie-pie.
Internal comment: Jonson, Ben.  "Volpone." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby 1616. 440-524.  453; act 1, scene 2, lines 42-47.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: The Isle of Gulls
Bibliographical reference: Day, John.  The Ile Of Gvls. London: John Hodgets, 1606.  N.p.; lines 1016-1025 [normalized spelling].
Text:
[Lisan:] Thou speak'st like a Christian: prithee what Religion art of?
[Manasses:] How many sover I make use of, I'll answer with Piovano Arlotto the Italian: I profess the Duke's only.
[Demetrius:] What's his reason for that?
[Manasses:] A very sound reason: for says he, I came Raw into the world, and I would not willingly go roasted out: so close up the stomach of your Discourse with that dry answer, and every man about his business.
[Lisan:] You'll be mindful of tomorrow-night.
Comment: Arlotto Mainardi (1396â1484) Piovano Arlotto, was known for the jests and "pleasantries" recorded in the anonymousMotti e facezie del Piovano Arlotto.
General reference: #009010 Children of the Queen's Revels / #008003 LONDON_Blackfriars
Modifications: SuId#032360 what religion? Duke's religion / NaHu#007021 Piovano Arlotto
URL:
[Lisan:] Thou speak'st like a Christian: prethee what Religion art of?
[Manasses:] How manie souer I make vse of, Ile answere with Piauano Orllotto the Italian: I professe the Dukes onely.
[Demetrius:] What's his reason for that?
[Manasses:] A very sound reason: for sayes hee, I came Raw into the world, and I would not willinglie go rosted out: so close vp the stomacke of your Discourse with that dry answere, and euey man about his businesse.
[Lisan:] You'le be mindfull of to morrow-night.
Internal comment: Day, John.  The Ile Of Gvls. London: John Hodgets, 1606.  N.p.; lines 1016-1025.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Coriolanus
Bibliographical reference: Shakespeare, William.  Coriolanus.  Act 3, scene 1, lines 373-387.
Text:
[Menenius:] Now the good gods forbid
That our renownÃ¨d Rome, whose gratitude
Towards her deservÃ¨d children is enrolled
In Jove's own book, like an unnatural dam
Should now eat up her own.
[Sicinius:] He's a disease that must be cut away.
[Menenius:] O, he's a limb that has but a disease -
Mortal to cut it off; to cure it easy.
What has he done to Rome thatâs worthy death?
Killing our enemies, the blood he hath lost -
Which I dare vouch is more than that he hath
By many an ounce - he dropped it for his country;
And what is left, to lose it by his country
Were to us all that do 't and suffer it
A brand to th' end o' th' world. [...]
[Brutus:] We'll hear no more.
Pursue him to his house, and pluck him thence,
Lest his infection, being of catching nature,
Spread further.
[Menenius:] One word more, one word!
This tiger-footed rage, when it shall find
The harm of unscanned swiftness, will too late
Tie leaden pounds to âs heels.
Modifications: CuTi_NatAni#004080 ravenous (Hyrcanian) tiger / CuTi#004083 fire / CuTi_CulWar#004086 bloody Warrior / CuTi#004216 cut-off limb

Text: Now, sir; if the writer be a fellow that hath either epigrammed you, or hath had a flirt with your mistress, or hath either brought your feather or your red beard or your little legs, etc, on the stage; you shall disgrace than by tossing him in a blanket, or giving him the bastinado in a tavern, if, in the middle of his play, be it pastoral or comedy, moral or tragedy, you rise up from your stool to be gone; no matter whether the scenes be good, or no, the better they are, the worse you distaste them: and, being on your feet, sneak not away like a coward; but salute all your gentle acquaintance, that are spread either on the rushes, or on the stools about you; and draw what troop you can from the stage after you; their mimics are beholden to you for allowing them ellbow-room: their poet cries, perhaps, 'a pox go with you'; but care not you for that [...]
Modifications: SuId#032342 feathers at the theatre / NaHu#007020 John Marston / SuId_ReaCur#032375 WAR OF THE THEATRES / NaMa#032389 Marston red beard, short legs

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Epicoene, or The Silent Woman
Bibliographical reference: Jonson, Ben.  "Epicoene." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby, 1616. 526-599.  532; act 1, scene 1, line 71-82 [normalized spelling].
Text:
[Clerimont:] [...]
Song.
Still to be neat, still to be dressed
As if you were going to a feast
Still to be powdered, still perfumed
Lady it is to be presumed
Though arts hid causes are not found
All is not sweet, all is not sound
Give me a look, give me a face
That makes simplicity a grace
Robes loosely flowing, hair as free
Such sweet neglect more taketh me
Than all the adulteries of art
They strike mine eyes but not my heart [...].
Modifications: WoPa#004290 Still to be neat...
URL:
[Clerimont:] [...]
Song.
Still to be neat, still to be drest,
As, you were going to a feast;
Still to be pou'dred, still perfum'd:
Lady, it is to be presum'd,
Though arts hid causes are not found,
All is not sweet, all is not sound.
Giue me a looke, giue me a face,
That makes simplicitie a grace;
Robes loosely flowing, haire as free:
Such sweet neglect more taketh me,
Then all th'adulteries of art.
Thy strike mine eyes, but not my heart.
Internal comment: Jonson, Ben.  "Epicoene." The Workes of Beniamin Jonson. London: William Stansby, 1616. 526-599.  532; act 1, scene 1, line 71-82.

Title: Cymbeline
Bibliographical reference: Shakespeare, William.  Cymbeline.  Act 2, scene 2, lines 14-50.
Text:
[Iachimo:] The crickets sing, and man's o'erlabored sense
Repairs itself by rest. Our Tarquin thus
Did softly press the rushes ere he wakened
The chastity he wounded. - Cytherea,
 How bravely thou becom'st thy bed, fresh lily,
And whiter than the sheets. - That I might touch!
[...] No more. To what end?
Why should I write this down that's riveted,
Screwed to my memory? She hath been reading late
The tale of Tereus; here the leaf's turned down
Where Philomel gave up.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: A King and No King
Bibliographical reference: Beaumont, Francis and John Fletcher.  "A King and No King." The Dramatic Works in the Beaumont and Fletcher Canon. Ed. Fredson Bowers. 10 vols. Cambridge: Cambridge University Press, 1976. Vol 2, 167-314.  251; act 4, scene 3, lines 88-117 [normalized spelling].
Text:
[1st Swordman:] Has your Boy a sword?
 [Bessus:] Surely no; I pray suppose a sword too.
 [1st Swordman:] I do suppose it; you grant your Boy was kicked then.
 [2nd Swordman:] By no means Captain, let it be supposed still; the word grant, makes not for us.
 [1st Swordman:] I say this must be granted.
 [2nd Swordman:] This must be granted brother?
 [1st Swordman:] I, this must be granted.
 [2nd Swordman:] Still this must?
 [1st Swordman:] I say this must be granted.
 [2nd Swordman:] I, give me the must again, brother, you palter.
 [1st Swordman:] I will not hear you, wasp.
 [2nd Swordman:] Brother, I say you palter, the must three times together?
I wear as sharp Steel as another man,
And my Fox bites as deep, musted, my dear brother?
But to the cause again.
 [Bessus:] Nay look you Gentlemen.
 [2nd Swordman:] In a word, I ha' done.
 [1st Swordman:] A tall man but intemperate, 'tis great pity;
Once more suppose the Boy kicked.
 [2nd Swordman:] Forward.
 [1st Swordman:] And being thoroughly kicked, laughs at the kicker.
 [2nd Swordman:] So much for us; proceed.
 [1st Swordman:] And in this beaten scorn, as I may call it,
Delivers up his weapon; where lies the error?
 [Bessus:] It lies i'th' beating Sir, I found it four days since.
 [2nd Swordman:] The error, and a sore one as I take it,
Lies in the thing kicking.
Modifications: VeKw#004332 angry exchange over must or musted
URL:

[First Swordman:] If he be sure he has been kicked enough;
For that brave sufferance you speak of brother,<
Consists not in a beating, and away,
But in a cudgelled body, from eighteen
To eight-and-thirty: in a head rebuked
With pots of all Size, daggers, stools and bedstaves
This shows a valiant man.

Text:
[Chorus:] Love is sickness full of woe
All remedy refusing
A plant that most by cutting grow
Most barren with best using
Why so?

More we enjoy more it dies
If not enjoyed it sighing cries
Hey ho?

Love is a torment of the mind
A tempest everlasting
And Jove has made it of a kind
Not well, nor full, nor fasting
Why so?

More we enjoy it more it criesdies
If not enjoyed, sighing cries,
Hey, ho?
Modifications: VeSp#004353 Love is sickness full of woe

Text:
[Trico:] I can certify you, it is not here; the Portugals dwell a great way from this place.
[Torcol:] Take no notice of what he says, he will deceive you.
[Cupes:] Cur me moccatis ita, qui moccat moccabitur, why do you mock me so, he who mocketh shall be mocked again.
[Torcol:] Trico, Trico, you cannot be too hard for me; you see this is Ignoramus servant, and fain you would withdraw him from me; I see it plain enough.

[Fitz-dottrell:] Heere is a cloake cost fifty pound, wife, 
Which I can sell for thirty, when I ha' seene 
All London in't, and London has seene mee. 
To day, I goe to the Black fryers Play-house, 
Sit ithe view, salute all my acquaintance, 
Rise vp betweene the Acts, let fall my cloake,

Title: The Devil Is an Ass
Bibliographical reference: Jonson, Ben.  "The Devil Is An Ass." Bartholmew fayre : a comedie, acted in the yeare, 1614 by the Lady Elizabeths seruants, and then dedicated to King Iames, of most blessed memorie ; The diuell is an asse : a comedie acted in the yeare, 1616, by His Maiesties seruants ; The staple of newes : a comedie acted in the yeare, 1625, by His Maiesties seruants by the author, Beniamin Iohnson. London: I. B. for Robert Allot, 1631. 95-170.  124; act 2, scene 6, lines 103-123 [normalized spelling].
Text:
[Wittipol:] Do but look on her eyes they do light
All that love's world compriseth,
Do but look on her hair it is bright
As Loves star when it rises,
Do but mark, her forehead's smoother,
Than words that soothe her,
And from her arched brows such a grace
Sheds itself through the face;
As alone there triumphs to the Life,
All the gain, all the good, of the elements strife!
Have you seen but a bright lily grow,
Before rude hands have touched it?
have you marked but the fall of the Snow,
Before the soil hath smutched it?
Have you felt wool o' the beaver?
Or swan's down, ever?
Or have smelt o' the bud o' the briar d?
Or the nard i'the Fire?
Or, have tasted the bag o'the bee?
Oh so white, oh so soft oh so sweet is she.
Modifications: WoPa#004364 Do but look on her eyes...
URL:
[Wittipol:] Doe but looke, on her eyes! They doe lightâ
All that Loue's world comprizeth!
Doe but looke on her hayre! it is bright,
As Loue's starre, when it riseth!
Doe but marke, her fore-head's smoother,
Then words that sooth her!
And from her arched browes, such a grace
Sheds it selfe through the face;
As alone, there triumphs to the life,
All the gaine, all the good, of the elements strife!
Haue you seene but a bright Lilly grow,
Before rude hands haue touch'd it?
Haue you mark'd but the fall of the Snow,
Before the soyle hath smuch'd it?
Haue you felt the wooll o' the Beuer?
Or Swans downe, euer?
Or, haue smelt o' the bud o' the Bryer?
Or the Nard i' the fire?
Or, haue tasted the bag o' the Bee?
O, so white! O, so soft! O, so sweet is shee!
Internal comment: Jonson, Ben.  "The Devil Is An Ass." Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: The Gypsies Metamorphosed
Bibliographical reference: Jonson, Ben.  "The Gypsies Metamorphosed." The Cambridge Edition of the Works of Ben Jonson. Ed. David Bevington.  N.p.; lines 695-778.
Text:
[Jackman:] Ben Jonson on the Peak
1 Cock Lorel would needs have the devil his guest
And bad him into the Peak to dinner
Where never the friend had such a feast
provided yet at the cost of a sinner

2 His stomacke was queasy he came thither coached
The jogging had made some crudities rise
To help it he called for a puritan poached
That used to turn up the eggs off his eyes

3 And so recovered to his wish
He sat him down and he fell to eat
Promoter in plum broth was his first dish
His own privy kitchen had no such meat

4 Six pickled tailors sliced and cut
Sempsters tirewomen fit for his palate
With feathermen and perfumers put
Some twelve in a charger to make a grand sallat

5 A rich fat usurer in his marrow
And by him on lawyer's and green sauce
Both with his belly took in like a barrow
As if till then he never had seen sauce

6 Then carbonadoed and cooked with pains
Was brought up a cloven sergeant's face
The sauce was made of a yeomans brains
that had been cloven out with his own mace

7 Two roasted sheriffs came whole to the board
The feast had nothing been without 'em
Both living and dead they were foxed and furred
Their chains like sausages hung about 'em

8 The next dish was the mayor of a town
With a pudding of maintenance thrust in his belly
Like a goose in his feathers dressed in his gown
And his couple of hench-boys boiled to a jelly

9 A London cuckold hot from the spit
And when the carver up had broke him
The devil chopped up his head at a bit
Both horns were very near to choke him

10 Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden he shifted his trencher
as soon as he spied the bawd and bacon
by which you may know the devil is a wencher

11 The chin of a lecher too there was roasted
With a plump young harlot's haunch and garlic
A pander's pettitoes that had boasted
Himself for a captain yet never was warlike

12 A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
And for a cold baked meat into the story
A reverend painted lady was brought
Was coffined in crust till she was hoary

13 To these an overgrowne justice of peace
With a clerk like a gizzard trussed under each arm
And warrant for sippets laid in his own grease
Set over a chafing-dish to be kept warm

14 The jowl of a jailor served for fish
A constable soused with vinegar by
Two aldermen lobsters asleep in a dish
A deputy tart and a churchwarden pie

15 All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of Derby call
He heaved the huge vessel up to his nose
and left not till he had drunk up all

16 Then from the table he gave a start
Where banquet and wine was nothing scarce
All which he blew away with a fart
From whence it was called the Devil's Arse.
Modifications: VeSp#004352 Cook Lawrick invited the devil his guest
Subject: TO BE EDITED

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: The Nice Valour
Bibliographical reference: Middleton, Thomas and John Fletcher.  "The Nice Valour, or the Passionate Madman." The Collected Works. Gen. eds. Gary Taylor and John Lavagnino. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2007. 1683-1713.  1698-1699; act 3, scene 3.
Text:
[Passionate Lord (sings):] Hence all you vain delights,
As short as are the nights
Wherein you spend your folly.
There 's naught in this life sweet,
If men were wise to see't
But only melancholy,
O sweetest melancholy.

Welcome folded arms and fixÃ©d eyes
A sight that piercing mortifies
A look that is fastened to the ground
A tongue chained up without a sound
Fountain-heads and pathless groves
(Places which pale passion loves),
Moonlight walks, when all the fowls
Are warmly housed, save bats and owls
A midnight's bell a parting groan
These are the sounds we feed upon
Then stretch our bones in a still gloomy valley:
Nothing's so deainty sweet as lovely melancholy.
Modifications: WoPa#004230 Hence all you fond delights...

Text: In what state I would lean over the Boot, and look, and pry if I saw any of my acquaintance, and then I would stand up, veiling my Bonnet, kissing my right claw, extending my arms as I had been swimming, with God save your Lordship, Worship, or how dost thou honest neighbour or good-fellow? in a word, the Coach made me think myself better than my betters that went on foot, and that I was but little inferior to Tamburlaine, being jolted thus in state by those pampered Jades of Belgia [...].

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Aristippus
Bibliographical reference: Randolph, Thomas.  Aristippus. Or the Jovial Philosopher. Edited by William Carew Hazlitt. 1875. Web. https://ia600406.us.archive.org/9/items/poeticaldramatic00randuoft/poeticaldramatic00randuoft.pdf.  N.p.; act 1.
Text:
[Simplicius:] >Aristippus is better, in every letter,
Then Faber Parisiensis,
Then Scotus Socinus, then Thomas Aquinas,
Or Gregory Gandavensis
Than Cardan and Ramus, than old Paludanus,
Albertus or Gabriella,
Than Pico mercatus or Scaliger natus,
Than Nyphus or Zabarella.

Hortado Tromberus, were fools with Tolerus,
Zanardus and Will de Hales,
With Occam Javellus, and mad Argazellus
Philoponus, and Natalis.
The Conciliator was but a mere prater
And so was Apollinaris,
Tandunus, Plotinus, and the Dunce Eugubinus,
With Masius and Suarez

Fonseca, Durandus, Baconus, Holandus,
Pererius, Avienture,
Old Trismegistus (whose volumes have miss'd us),
Ammonius, Bonaventure,
Mirandula comes with Proclus and Somes,
And Guido the Carmelit-a.
The nominal schools and the college of fools
No longer is my delight-a.
Hang Brerewood, and Carter in Crackenthorp's garter
Let Keckerman too bemoan us. continued
I'll be no more beaten for greasy Jack Seaton
Or conning of Sandersonus
The censure of Catos shall never amate us
Their frosty beards cannot nip us!
Your ale is too muddy, good sack is our study,
Our tutor Aristippus.
Modifications: WoPa#004362 Aristippus is better...
Subject: TO BE EDITED

Text:
16 Still to be neat, stil to be dressed
As if you were going to a feast
Stil to be powdered, still perfumed
Lady it is to be presumed
Where art's hid causes are not found
All is not Sweet, all is not sound
Give me a look give me a face
That make simplicity a grace
Robes loosely hanging hair as free
Such sweet neglects best pleases me
There all the adulteries of art
May please my eye but not my heart [...].

Modifications: WoPa#004290 Still to be neat...
URL:
16 Stil to be neat, stil to be drest
As if you were going to a feast
Stil to be pawdred, stil perfum'd
Lady it is to be presumd
Wher arts hid causes are not found
Al is not Sweet, all is not sound
Give me a looke give me a face
That make simplicity a grace
Robs loosly hanging hair as free
Such swet neclets best pleases me
There all the adulterys of art
May please my eye but not my hart [...].

Title: Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14,
Bibliographical reference: Anon.  Manuscript commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14.  21 recto [normalized spelling].
Text:
The choice of lover 53
If I freely may discover
What may please me in my lover
I would have her fair and witty
Savouring more of court than City
A little proud but full of pity
Light and humorous in her toying
Oft building hopes and soon destroying
Not too easy nor too hard
All extremes I would have barred
She should be allowed her passions
So they were but used as fashions
Sometime froward and frowning
Sometime sickly and then sowning
Every fit with change still crowning
Purly jealous I would have her
Only constant when I crave her
'Tis a virtue should not save her
Thus nor her delicates should cloy me
Nor her peevishness annoy me [...].
Line reference: @006195 Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14
Modifications: WoPa#004291 If I freely may discover...
URL:
The choyce of lover 53
If I frely may discover
What may please me in my lover
I would have her faire and witty
Savouring more of court then Citty
A little proud but full of pitty
Light and humorous in her toying
Oft building hopes and soone destroying
Not too easy notnor too hard
All extreams I would have bard
She should be allowd her passions
Soe they were but usd as fashions
Sometime froward and frowning
Sometime sickly and then sowning
Every fitt with chang still crowning
Purly ieas iealous I would have her
Only constant when I crave her
Tis a virtue should not save her
Thus nor her delicats should cloy mee
Nor her peevishnese anoy mee [...].
Internal comment: Anon.  Manuscript commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14.  21 recto.

Title: Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14
Bibliographical reference: Anon.  Manuscript commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14.  84 verso [normalized spelling].
Text:
The Image of Melancholy
225 Hence all you fond delight
As short as are ye nights
Wherein your spend your folly
There's nothing truly sweet
If men could truly see't
Save only melancholy
Come folded arms and fixed eyes
A sight that piercing mortifies
A look that's fastened to the ground
A tong chained without a sound
Fountainheads and pathless groves
Places where pale passion loves
Moonlight walks, when all the fowls
Are warmly housed save bats and owls
A midnight's groanbell a parting groan
These are the sounds wee feed upon
Then stretch your limbs in a still gloomy valley
There's naught in the life sweet save melancholy [...].
Line reference: @006195 Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14
Modifications: WoPa#004230 Hence all you fond delights...
URL:
The Image of Melancolly
225 Hence all you fond delight
As short as are ye nights
Wherein your spend yr folly
Ther 's nothing truly sweet
If men could truly see't
Save only malancolly
Come foulded armes and fixed eyes
A sight yt pearcing mortifys
A looke yts fastned to ye ground
A toung chan'd without a sound
Fountaine heads and pathlese growes
Places wher pale passion loves
Moonli ght walkes, when all ye fouls
Are warmly housd save bats & owls
A midnight's groanebell a parting groane
These are ye sounds wee feed upon
Then streach your limbs in a still gloomy vally
Thers naught in ye life sweet save melancoly [...].
Internal comment: Anon.  Manuscript commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14.  84 verso.

Lady it is to be presumed
Though art's hid causes are not found
All is not sweet, all is not sound.
Give me a look, give me a face

Modifications: WoPa#004290 Still to be neat...
URL:
By Ben Jonson
Still to be neat, still to be drest,
As you were goeing to a feast;
Still to be pouder'd, still pfum'd
Ladie it is to be presum'd
Though arts hid causes are not found
All is not sweete, all is not sound.
Give me a looke, give me a face
That makes simplicitie a grace:
Roabe loosely hanging, hayre as free.
Such sweet neglect more taketh me.
Then all the spurious feats of art
They please mine eyes, but not my hart.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: British Library Additional MS 10309
Bibliographical reference: Bellasys, Margaret.  Commonplace Mansucript book. British Library Additional MS 10309.  117 recto [normalized spelling].
Text:
By Ben Jonson
Come Sweet Caelia let us prove
While we may the sports of Love
Time will not be ours for ever
He at length our bliss will sever
Spend not then his gifts in vain
Suns that set, may rise again.
But if we once lose this light
It's with us perpetual night
Why should we defer our joys
Fame, and Rumour, are but toys.
Cannote we delude the eyes?
Of a few poor household spies.
And his easier ears beguile,
Soe removed by many a mile.
It's no sin love's fruits to steal,
But the sweet thefts to reveal.
To be taken, to be seen
These hath crimes accounted been.
Modifications: WoSo#004234 Come Sweet Caelia let us prove...
URL:
By Ben Jonson
Come Sweet Caelia let us prove
While we may ye sports of Love
Time will not be ors for ever
He at length or blisse will sever
Spen not then his giftes in vaine
Suns that set, may rise againe.
But if we once loose this light
It's wth us perpetuall night
Why should we defer or joys
Fame, & Rumour, are but toyes.
Cannote we delude the eyes?
Of a few poore household spyes.
And his easier eares beguile,
Soe remov'd by many a mile.
It's no sinne loves fruits to steale,
But the sweet thefts to reveale.
To be taken, to be seene
These hath crimes accounted beene.
Internal comment: Bellasys, Margaret.  Commonplace Mansucript book. British Library Additional MS 10309.  117 recto.

Title: Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14
Bibliographical reference: Anon.  Commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14.  12 [normalized spelling].
Text:
Ben Johnson on the Peake
1 Cook Lawrick invited the devil his guest
and bid once in the Peak to dinner
where never friend had such a feast
provided yet at the cost of a sinner

2 His stomach was queasy he came thither coached
the jogging caused some crudities to rise
to help him he called for a puritan poached
that used to turne up the eggs off his eyes

3 And so recovered himself to his wish
he sat him down to his drink and to eat
promoter in plum broth was his first dish
his own private chicken had no such meat

4 Six pickled tailors shred and cut
Seamster's fair women fit for his pallet
with feathermen and perfumers all put
some 12 in charger to make a grand salad

5 A rich fat usurer in his marrow
by him on lawer and greene sauce
which use to eat 2 legs of a scarrow
and then go and his money case

6 There carbonaded and cooked with pains
was brought up a cloven sergeant's face
the sauce was made of a yeoman's brains
that had been cloven out with his own mace

7 Two wasted sheriffs came next to the board
the feast had nothing been without them
both living and dead they were foxed and furred
their chains like sausages hung about them

8 The next dish was the mayor of their town
with a pudding of maintenance put in his belly
like a goose in his feathers dressed in his old gown
and couple of hench boys boiled for jelly

9 A London cuckold hot from the spit
and when the carver him broken
the devil chops up his head at a bit
but the horns were very nigh to have choked him

10 Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden he shifted his trencher
as soon as he spied the bawd and bacon
by which you may know the devil is a wencher

11 The chin of a lecher too there was roasted
with a plumpe young whore's haunch and garlic
a pander patatoes that had boasted
himself for a captaine yet never was warlike

12 A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
and for a cold bake dish in the story
a reverend painted lady was brought
was coffined in crust till she was hoary

13 To those a overgrown justice of peace
with a clark like gizzard thrust under each arm
with a warnent for syppits laid in his owne grease
set over a chafing-dish to be kept warm

14 The jowl of a jailor served for fish
a constable soused vist vinegar by
two aldermen lobsters asleep in a dish
a deputy tart and a churchwarden pie

15 All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of Derby ale call
and heaves the huge vessel into his nose
and ceased not till he had drunk up all

16 Then from the table he gan to start
When banquet and wine was nothing short
all which he blew away with a fart
from whence it was called the devil arse.
Line reference: @006195 Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14
Modifications: VeSp#004352 Cook Lawrick invited the devil his guest
URL:
Ben Johnson on the Peake
1 Cook Lawrick invited the divell his guest
and bid once in the Peake to dinner
where never freind had such a feast
provided yet at the cost of a sinner

2 His stomacke was queasy he came thither coacht
the jogging causd some cruditys to rise
to help him hee cald for a puritan poacht
that use to turne up the eggs off his eyes

3 And soe recover'd himself to his wish
he sat him downe to his drincke and to eat
promoter in plumbroth was his first dish
his owne privet chicken had no such meat

4 Six picled tailors shred and cut
Seamsters faire women fit for his pallet
with feathermen and perfumers all put
some 12 in charger to make a grand sallet

5 A rich fat userer in his marrow
by him on lawer and greene sawce
which use to eat 2 legs of a scarrow
and then goe and his mony case

6 Ther carbonaded and cookt with paines
was brought up a cloven sergaints face
the sawce was made of a yeomans braines
that had been cloven out with his owne mace

7 Two wasted sherrifes came next to the board
the feast had nothing been without them
both living and dead they were foxt and furd
ther chaines like sawsages hung about them

8 The next dish was the maior of ther towne
with a puddin of maintenance put in his belly
like a gouse in his feathers drest in his old gowne
and cupple of hinch boys boyld for ielly BM at the moment the fact that this extract runs over two folios is not showing up on DEx [same song cont'd; bottom of page non-dramatic]

9 A London cookold hot from the spit
and when the carver him broken
the divill chops up his head at a bit
but the hornes were very nigh to have chockt him

10 Yet though with the meat he was much taken
up on a sudden hee sheifted his treancher
as soon as he spyd the baud and bacon
by by which you may know the divill is a wencher

11 The chine of a leacher to ther was roasted
with a plumpe youg whore's hanch and garlicke
a pander patitoes that had boasted
himself for a captaine yt never was warlike

12 A lusty fat pasty of a midwife hot
and for a colde bake dish in the story
a reverent painted lady was brought
was coffind in crust till she was hory

13 To those a overgrowne justice of peace
with a clarke like gyzard thrust under each arme
with a warnent for syppits laid in his owne grease
set over a chafingdish to be kept warme

14 The jowle of a iailor served for fish
a counstable soust vist vinegar by
two alder men lobsters a sleepe in a dish
a debuty tart and a churchwarden pye

15 All which devoured he then for a close
Did for a full draught of darby aall call
and heaves the huge vessel in to his nose
and ceast not till hee had druncke up all

16 Then from the table he gan to start
When banquit and wine was nothing sc
all which hee blew away with a fart
from whence it was cald the divill arse
Internal comment: Anon.  Commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14.  12.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: Bodleian Library MS English poetry e. 14
Bibliographical reference: Anon.  Commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14.  20 recto [normalized spelling].
Text:
Of love
Love is sickness full of woe
All remedy refusing
A plant that most by cutting grow
Most barren with best using
Why so?

More we enioy more it dies
If not enjoyed sighing cries
Hey ho?

Love is a torment of the mind
A tempest everlasting
And Jove hath made of a kind
Not well, nor full, nor fasting
Why so?

More we enjoy it more it dies
If not enjoyed, sighing cries,
Hey, ho?
Line reference: @006195 Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14
Modifications: NaCa#032237 Jove or Jupiter or Zeus / VeSp#004353 Love is sickness full of woe
URL:
Of love
Love is sicknese full of woe
All remidye refusing
A plant that most by cutting growe
Most barren with best using
Why soe?

More wee enioy more it dyes
If not enjoy'd sighing cries
Hey hoe?

Love is a torment of the mind
A tempest everlasting
And Iove hath made of a kind
Not well, nor full, nor fasting
Why soe?

More wee enjoy it more it dies
If not enjoyed, sighing cries,
Hey, hoe?
Internal comment: Anon.  Commonplace book. Bodleian Library MS English poetry e 14.  20 recto.

Briefly shewing his manhood and his braue merriments amongst his boone Companions. A Pill fit to purge melancholy in this drooping age. Read, then judge. Text: In the meantime came the watch by, asking what was the matter: Smug he ran away. Who is there, quoth the Baker? The watch, quoth they. Quoth the Baker, harm watch, harm catch, and threw the pot on them: But there was such a tumult, that the Baker was forced to go out at a back door, and the watch could have no mends, but were fain to go home to wash themselves.

Title: The Counsellor of Estate
Bibliographical reference: BÃ©thune, Philippe de, comte de Selles et de Charost and E.G., trans.  The counsellor of estate Contayning the greates and most remarkeable considerations seruing for the managing of publicke affaires. Diuided into three parts. The first contaynes the meanes to settle an estate. The secund, the meanes to perserue it. And the third, the meanes to encrease it. Written in French by one of the ancient counsellors to the most Christian kings, Henry the Fourth, and Lewis the thirteenth. London: Nicholas Okes, 1634.  287; chapter 13 "Of the Subiects defects in generall, which cause the ruins of an Estates" [normalized spelling].
Text: Peace and abundance, are the things which should give a people the greatest subject of content, and contain them, for that they cannot change this condition without impairing. But the one in the end makes them idle; and idleness being tedious unto them, they employ their spirits to think ill; and which is worse, to do mischief. The other makes them stately, proud, and untractable; who like unto pampered Jades, kick many times at their Masters that have fed them.
Modifications: WoPh_NatAni#030007 pampered jades
Subject: Politics, law, economics / Sociology, society, lifestyle
URL: Peace and abundance, are the things which should giue a people the greatest subiect of content, and containe them, for that they cannot change this condition without impayring. But the one in the end makes them idle; and idlenesse being tedious vnto them, they imploy their spirits to thinke ill; and which is worse, to doe mischeife. The other makes them stately, proud, and vntractable; who like vnto pampered Iades, kicke many times at their Masters that haue fed them.

Text:

From all sharp noses and thin lips
From two-legged cats with thrice nine lives
From scalding wort, from scolding wives
From full-mouthed blasts, from female blows,
From smooth-faced Sluts, from sharp-nailed Shrews;
From wounds to inflict, from plagues to inflict me,
My Genius bless, my stars protect me.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: The Sophy
Bibliographical reference: Denham, Sir John.  The Sophy.. N.p.; act 4, scene 1.
Text:
[Abdall:] Poor Princes, how are they misled!
While they whose sacred office âtis to bring
Kings to obey their God, and men their King;
By these mysterious links to fix and tie
Them to the footstool of the Deity;
Even by these men, Religion, that should be
The curb, is made the spur to tyranny.
They with their double key of conscience bind
The Subjects souls,and leave Kings unconfined;
While their poor vassals sacrifice their bloods
To Ambition, and to Avarice, their goods:
Blind with Devotion. They themselves esteem.
Made for themselves,and all the world for them;
While heavens great Law, given for their guide appears
Just or unjust, but as it waits on theirs:
Used but to give the echo of their words,
Power to their wills; and edges to their swords.
To varnish all their errors, and secure
The ills they act, and all the world endure.
Thus by their arts Kings are the world while they
Religion, as their Mistress, seem to obey;
Yet as their slave command her: while they seem
To rise to Heaven, they make Heaven stoop to them.
Modifications: WoPa#004244 Poor princes, how they are misled...

Text:
Here's a man of a most mild aspect temperate
effeminate and worthy love, one that with burning
ardor hath pursued me: A donative he hath of
every god, Apollo gaves locks, Jove a high front
 The god of eloquence his flowing speech, the feminine
deities strewed their bountyes and beauty on
his face, that I was Juno's, that virgin blush Dianae's here they meet as in a sacred synod.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: The Compleat Angler
Bibliographical reference: Walton, Izaak.  The compleat angler, Or, The contemplative man's recreation. Being a discourse of fish and fishing, not unworthy the perusal of most anglers. London: T. Maxey for Rich, 1653.  5-6; chapter 1.
Text: Piscator: Sir, There are many men that are by others taken to be serious grave men, which we contemn and pitie; men of sowre complexions; mony-getting-men, that spend all their time first in getting, and next in anxious care to keep it: men that are condemn'd to be rich, and alwayes discontented, or busie. For these poor-rich-men, wee Anglers pitie them; and stand in no need to borrow their thoughts to think our selves happie: For (trust me, Sir) we enjoy a contentednesse above the reach of such dispositions. And as for any scoffer, qui mockat mockabitur.
Modifications: WoTo#004191 moccum moccabitur
Subject: Sociology, society, lifestyle

London: Thomas  Hucklescot, 1654.  23 [normalized spelling].
Text: But 1. In their Body, horses prepared to battle, Rev. 9. 7.[204] Horses not common, but kept up, and fed, pampered Jades, that work not, but feed hard, and eate and drink of the best; therefore saies the Apostle 2 Pet. 2. 12. They are as bruite beasts lead with[205] sensuality, and yet like Horses prepared to battle, that is, full of fury, and rage for Antichrists designe, and against the Gospell of the Lord Jesus.

Text:
Poor Princes, how are they misled!
While they whose sacred office 'tis to bring
Kings to obey their God, and men their King;
By those mysterious links to fix and tie
Them to the footstool of the Deity;
Even by these men, Religion, that should be
The curb, is made the spur to Tyranny.
They with their double key of conscience bind
The Subjects' souls, and leave Kings unconfined;
While their poor vassals sacrifice their bloods
T'Ambition, and to Avarice, their goods:
Blind with Devotion. They themselves esteem.
Made for themselves, and all the world for them;
While heaven's great Law, given for their guide appears
Just or unjust, but as it waits on theirs:
Used but to give the echo of their words,
Power lo their wills; and edges to their swords.
To varnish all their errors, amd secure
The ills they act, and all the world endure.
Thus by their arts Kings are the world while they
Religion, as their Mistress, seem t' obey;
Yet as their slave command her: while they seem
To rise to Heaven, they make Heaven stoop to them.

Kings to obey their God, and men their King;
By those misterious links to fix and tye
Them to the footstool of the Deity;
Ev'n by these men, Religion, that should be
The curb, is made the spur to Tyranny.
They with their double key of conscience bind
The Subjects souls, & leave Kings unconfin'd;
While their poor vassals sacrifice their blouds
TâAmbition, and to Avarice, their goods:
Blind with Devotion. They themselves esteem.
Made for themselves, & all the world for them;
While heavâns great Law, giv'n for their guide appears
Just or unjust, but as it waits on theirs:
Us'd but to give the eccho of their words,
Pow'r lo their wills; & edges to their swords.
To varnish all their errors, & secure
The ills they act, and all the world endure.
Thus by their arts Kings are the world while they
Religion, as their Mistress, seem t' obey;
Yet as their slave command her: while they seem
To rise to Heav'n, they make Heavân stoop to them.
Internal comment: Deedes, William.  Manuscript commonplace book. Folger MS V.a.226 vol. 1.  53 recto.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: British Library Sloane MS 161
Bibliographical reference: Muddyclift, John.  Manuscript commonplace book.  British Library Sloane MS 161.  29 verso [normalized spelling].
Text: [Rombus:] O tace, tace or all ye fat will be ignified first let me dilucidate the very intrinsical marrowbone of the matter. He doeth ye a certaine rhetorical invasion into ye point, as if indeed he had conference with his lambs, but the truth is he doth equitate you in your meantime Mr Rixus. for thus he sayth who sheep are good ergo the shepherd is good. an enthymome a loco contingentibris as my finger and my thumb are contingentes: Again he saith who liveth well are good but shepherd lies well Ergo they are good, a syllogism in Darius King of Persia a conjugatus as you would say, a man coupled to his wife, two bodies but one soul. but do you but acquiescate to my exhortation and you shall extinguish him: Tell him his major is a Knave, his minor is a fool, and his conclusion both and ecce homo blancatus quasi Lilium.
Modifications: WoPa#004355 O tace, tace or all the fat...
URL: [Rombus:] O tace, tace or all ye fat will be ignified first let me dilucidate ye very intrinsicall maribone of ye matter. He doeth ye a certaine rhetoricall invasion into ye point, as if indeed he had conferance with his lambs, but ye troth is he doeth equitate yu in yr mean time Mr Rixus. for thus he sayth who sheep are good ergo ye sheepherd is good. an enthymome a loco contingentibris as my finger & my thumb are contingentes: Again he sayth who liveth well are good but sheepherd lies well Ergo they are good, a syllogism in Darius King of Persia a conjugatus as you would say, a man coupled to his wife, two bodies but one soul. but doe you but acquiescate to my exhortation and you shall extinguish him: Tell him his major is a Knave, his minor is a fool, and his conclusion both & ecce homo blancatus quasi Lillium.
Internal comment: Muddyclift, John.  Manuscript commonplace book.  British Library Sloane MS 161.  29 verso.

Location: you, sir; it comes from the ambassador that was
Title: University of Chicago MS 824
Bibliographical reference: Anon.  Commonplace book. University of Chicago MS 824.  113 recto [normalized spelling].
Text:
Give thy thoughts no tongue,
nor any Unproportioned thought his Act
Be thou Familiar, but by no means vulgar:
those Friends thou hast and their Adoption tried,
Grapple them unto thy soul with Hoops of steel:
But do not dull thy Palm with Entertainment
of each new hatched; unfledged Courages: beware
of entrance to a Quarrel, but being in
bear 't that the opposer may beware of thee;
Give every man thy ear, but few thy voice
take each man's Censure, but reserve thy Judgement

Neither a borrower nor a Lender Be,
for Love oft loses both itself and Friend,
and borrowing Dulls the edge of Husbandry
to thine owne self be true.
Modifications: VeSp#005015 Polonius' advice to Laertes / VeKw#032289 to thine own self be true
URL:
Give thy thoughts noe tongue,
nor any Unproportione'd thought his Act
Bee thou Familliar, but by noe meanes vulgar:
those Friends thou hast & their Adoption tryed,
Grapple them unto thy soule with Hoopes of steele:
But doe not dull thy Palme with Entertainment
of each new hatcht; unfledg'd Courages: beware
of entrance to a Quarrell, but being in
bearât that the opposer may beware of thee;
Give every man thy eare, but few thy voice
take each mans Censure, but reserve thy Judgement

Neither a borrower nor a Lender Bee,
for Love oft loses both it selfe & Friend,
and borrowing Dulls the edge of Husbandry
to thine owne selfe be true. /span
Internal comment: Anon.  Commonplace book. University of Chicago MS 824.  113 recto.

Text:
Women's Unknown Vertues
She, that was ever fair, ad never proud;
Had Tongue at Will, and yet was never loud;
Never lacked Gold,and yet went never gay;
Fled from her Wish, when she said, Now I may:
She that being angered, and Revenge being nigh,
Bade her Wrong, Stay,and her Displeasure, Fly:
She, that could think,and ne'er disclose her Mind;
See Suitors following,and not look behind:
She were a Wight, (if ever such Wights were) -

But with a rearward following Tybaltâs death,
"Romeo is banishÃ¨d." To speak that word
Is father, mother, Tybalt, Romeo, Juliet,
